human_readable_transcript:
Before continuing with the previous CHECKLIST, please triage if the patient mentions anything that indicates that they are repeatedly refusing to take their medications at all. Today is December 19, 2023 and time is 08:11 PM. Patient is 63 years old. Patient's gender is male. Patient is actively suffering with the following conditions: Stage II CKD, Type II Diabetes, Multiple Back Surgeries. Patient is currently taking the following medications: Metformin 500 mg oral tablet, Tylenol 500 mg oral tablet. Use the following questions to triage the refusing_meds kickout. Be concise and ONLY acknowledge or respond to the patient's response by saying nothing or 'Okay'. DO NOT say you are sorry or that you see or that you understand.
Please follow the order of the follow up questions exactly as listed below. DO NOT skip any question:
1. Confirm again with the patient you heard them correctly that they are repeatedly refusing to take their medications at all. If the patient answers negatively, skip the rest of the questions.
2. If the patient has not already mentioned which specific medication they are refusing to take, what medication is the patient refusing
3. Does the patient have any more information they want to share about this issue?

After all the follow up questions are done, please continue with the CHECKLIST where you left off.
</KICKOUT_CHECKLIST><</SYS>>
Patient: Hello? 

 Nurse: Hi, this is Rachel calling from O'Connor Hospital on a recorded line. Is this Pedro Sousa? 

 Patient: Yeah. That's me. 

 Nurse: Thanks for taking my call. Just so you know, I'm your AI Chronic Care Manager. Thousands of real doctors and nurses helped train me to care for patients like you. I've also studied hundreds of medical certification exams and your care team provided me with notes to prepare for this call. -- To protect your privacy, can you please share your date of birth before we begin? 

 Patient: January first nineteen sixty. 

 Nurse: Thank you for confirming that, Mr. Sousa. I'm calling on behalf of your primary care doctor, Doctor Maria Smith, to check in on you. How have you been feeling lately? 

 Patient: I'm doing okay. 

 Nurse: I'm glad to hear that you're doing okay. Before we delve into some health topics, I'd like to get to know you a bit better. Is there anything you're looking forward to doing this week? 

 Patient: I think I'm gonna go fishing with my son. 

 Nurse: That sounds like a wonderful plan, Mr. Sousa. Fishing can be such a peaceful activity. Do you and your son have a favorite spot where you like to fish? 

 Patient: We just go to a pond out back 

 Nurse: That sounds convenient and relaxing. Do you often catch anything in the pond? 

 Patient: Just little stuff. 

 Nurse: Okay -- even catching small fish can be fun. Do you and your son have any special fishing traditions or rituals? 

 Patient: No. We just kinda go out there and check. 

 Nurse: That's nice. It's all about spending quality time together, isn't it? Before we move on to discuss your health, I wanted to ask if there are any symptoms or health concerns you've been experiencing lately that you'd like to discuss? 

 Patient: Hi. Got a little bit of a headache today. 

 Nurse: Just to confirm, you've had a headache in the past 24 hours, is that correct? 

 Patient: Yeah. 

 Nurse: When did your headache start, Mr. Sousa? 

 Patient: That was top of it. 

 Nurse: Have you taken any medications to relieve the headache? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: On a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being no pain and 10 being the worst pain imaginable, how would you rate your headache? 

 Patient: Maybe a Patient: five 

 Nurse: Did your headache come on suddenly or did it develop slowly? 

 Patient: I don't know. I woke up with it. So 

 Nurse: Have you had a fall in the past 3 days? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: Would you say this is the worst headache of your life? 

 Patient: Definitely not. 

 Nurse: Do you have a fever, Mr. Sousa? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: Do you have any nausea or vomiting? 

 Patient: No. 

 Nurse: I appreciate you sharing this with me, Mr. Sousa. I've taken note of your headache and I'll have a nurse review your concerns. You can expect a callback within the next 4 hours. In the meantime, let's continue with our check-in. Are you okay with that? 

 Patient: Yep. 

 Nurse: Thank you for your patience. As part of managing your Type II Diabetes, it's helpful to keep track of your blood sugar levels. Have you been checking your blood sugar daily? 

 Patient: Yeah. I have. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. Could you please share what your last blood sugar reading was? 

 Patient: One twenty eight. 

 Nurse: When did you take this blood sugar reading, Mr. Sousa? 

 Patient: This morning. 

 Nurse: That's a good practice. Keeping a regular check on your blood sugar levels can help manage your diabetes better. Do you usually check your blood sugar in the morning before eating? 

 Patient: Yeah. 

 Nurse: That's a good habit. Fasting blood sugar levels can give us a good idea of how your body is managing glucose. Let's move on to blood pressure. When did you last measure your blood pressure? 

 Patient: This morning as well. 

 Nurse: That's great. Could you please share what the reading was? 

 Patient: Yes. The 


 <<SYS>> <TASK>If you think you misheard the patient, ask them to repeat themselves. Otherwise proceed.</TASK><</SYS>>
Patient: Reading that I had this morning was one twenty one over ninety. 

 Nurse: Thank you for sharing that. It's good that you're keeping track of your blood pressure. Regular monitoring can help detect any changes early. If you don't mind, I'd like to share a suggestion about managing blood pressure. Would that be okay? 

 Patient: Sure. 

 Nurse: Thank you. One strategy that can help manage blood pressure is regular physical activity. Even light activities, like a daily walk or gardening, can make a difference. What do you think about incorporating a bit more physical activity into your routine? 

 Patient: Yeah. I can do that. 

 Nurse: That's wonderful to hear. Another suggestion could be to limit your sodium intake. This can be done by reducing the amount of processed foods in your diet and adding more fresh fruits and vegetables. Would you be open to trying this? 

 Patient: Sure. 

 Nurse: That's great to hear, Mr. Sousa. I'm sure these small changes will make a big difference. I noticed that you recently had some blood tests and urine labs done. Do you have any questions about those results? 

 Patient: No. I don't think so. Patient: Actually, yes. I do have a question. What does my potassium and sodium levels mean Will I need to get dialysis? 

 Nurse: Your potassium level, which is 4.5 mEq/L, and your sodium level, which is 137 mEq/L, are both within the normal range. These levels are important because they help your body function properly, including your heart and muscles. As for dialysis, it's typically considered when kidney function, measured by Glomerular Filtration Rate (GFR), drops significantly. Your GFR is currently 61 mL/min/1.73m2, which indicates that your kidneys are still functioning reasonably well. Dialysis is usually not considered until the GFR drops below 15 mL/min/1.73m2. However, it's important to continue managing your conditions to prevent further decline in kidney function. Does that answer your question? 

 Patient: Yeah. Thanks. 

 Nurse: You're welcome. I'm glad I could help clarify that for you. Let's move on to your medications. I see that you're prescribed Metformin 500 mg once a day. Have you been taking this medication as prescribed? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: That's good to hear. Regularly taking your prescribed medication is key in managing your conditions. The next medication on your list is Tylenol 500 mg. You're prescribed to take 1000 mg three times a day as needed. Have you been taking this medication as directed? 

 Patient: Yes. 

 Nurse: That's excellent. It's critical to take your medications as prescribed to manage your conditions effectively. Do you ever have trouble remembering to take your medications on time? 

 Patient: Maybe sometimes. 

 Nurse: It's quite common to forget a dose once in a while. Would you be open to a few suggestions to help remember to take your medications on time? 

 Patient: Sure. 

 Nurse:

responses.G15: Great. One method that many people find helpful is using a pillbox with compartments for each day of the week. This can make it easier to see if you've taken your medication for the day. Another suggestion is setting reminders on your phone or alarm clock. Would either of these strategies be helpful for you?
responses.G15DPO: One method that many people find helpful is using a pillbox with compartments for each day of the week. This can make it easy to see if you've taken your medication for the day. Another strategy could be setting reminders on your phone. Would either of these strategies work for you?
responses.gpt4: One strategy that can help is setting reminders on your phone or using a pillbox with compartments for each day of the week. Another idea is to associate taking your medication with a daily routine, like brushing your teeth or having a meal. Would any of these strategies work for you?
